Description: Bronze figure of the Apis bull: with inlaid silver eyes and a blaze on his forehead. He wears a sun disk with uraeus between his horns, a collar around his neck and a patterned blanket over his back. Two outstretched winged shapes are incised on his body; over his shoulders it is a winged scarab, at the end of his back a vulture. The figure was solid cast by the lost wax process. It was donated by a man called Padiese son of Horenpe whose name is incised on the base with a prayer to the Apis.
Curator's comments: Votive figures of the Apis are characteristic of the Late Period, when a cleansing of the Egyptian pantheon, from foreign influences, meant that ancient deities such as Ptah and his animal manifestation who preceded any such taint became especially popular. The donor would have presented this piece to be placed inside the temple at Memphis or in a chapel beside the Serapeum. Bibliography: B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' VIII (Oxford: Clarendon Press), p. 1121; 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 80-81 No 17.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.64-65)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1977 London, BM, Animals in Art
